titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Stephen Tennant Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:51

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: 15 August 2011 Acquisition: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, Inc. on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2011.
18 August 2011 Acquisition: Purchased from Maggs Brothers Ltd. on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2011.
1 August 2011 Acquisition: Purchased from Peter Harrington on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2011.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Stephen Tennant Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Stephen Tennant Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below and titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Stephen Tennant
bioghist.p: Stephen Tennant (1906 - 1987) was a British socialite and writer known as one of the "Bright Young People," a group of upper-class British artists, writers, and bon vivants during the 1920s. Tennant's friends and peers included Cecil Beaton and Rex Whistler and he had a brief, passionate affair with the poet Siegfried Sassoon. He befriended his favorite author, Willa Cather, and became a travelling companion to her partner, Edith Lewis, and he enjoyed close friendships with Daphne Du Maurier, Stephen Spender, Vita Sackville-West, and Elizabeth Bowen. Later in life Tennant withdrew from society, confining himself to his country estate for decades, producing sheaves of handwritten pages for a unfinished novel, "Lascar."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, printed material, artwork, and other related papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three groupings: 15 August 2011 Acquisition, 18 August 2011 Acquisition, and 1 August 2011 Acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, printed material, artwork, and other related papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, Inc. on the James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection Fund, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unpublished novel by Stephen Tennant. Contains: typescripts, manuscripts and various notes. Included are scene-directions, plot summaries and character analyses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unpublished novel by Stephen Tennant. Contains: typescript and carbon copies, as well as a manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: typescripts, manuscripts and various notes.

did.unittitle: "A Reassessment of Poetry" - Introduction to the Volume of Poetry, Call Rapture by its Name

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: typescripts, manuscripts and various notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: page proofs, manuscripts, and various notes. My Brother Aquarius was privately printed in 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains: 'The Lynx (The Wildcat)', 'But in Brief Longing' - a novel, 'The Public Rose Garden', 'With Canada on his Arm', 'The Night Nurse', and 'Edward & Nannie'.

did.unittitle: 'The Voice of the Lagoon', and other prose

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains: 'Wuffa: An Anglo-Saxon Fantasy', 'The Japanese Garden', 'Wake, wild visionary' - a poetic drama, 'The Hour Approaches', 'The Treat', and 'Garth Trevor Mattersaunt'.

did.unittitle: 'A Carriage for Miss Creighton', and other prose

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains: 'The Oriental Goods Store', 'The Exile' - a play, 'The Promise', 'Child Vision', and 'A Portrait of Modern Family Life'.

did.unittitle: 'The Road Beyond Death' by Dr. Hugo Fischer, and other prose

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hugo Fischer (1897-1975) was a German philospher, and resident of England between 1925-1938. Folder also contains: 'The Hepworths' - a short story, 'The Memory of a Crime', 'Old Glass' - a short story, 'The Promise' - a play, 'Tomorrow' - a short story, 'One Hour to Kill' - a comedy thriller, 'Holiday Love' - short story, 'The Old Man's Child', 'Man of the World', 'Poor Miss Taffy' - a short story, 'The Man Himself', 'Next Gentleman, please', and 'Luxury Item'.

did.unittitle: Various untiled plays, short stories and a ballet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains: 'The Curious Sea', 'England and Poetry', 'Pink Cherry Trees, near Portsmouth', 'Sacred Spring. 1971', 'Foxgloves', 'The Question - A Mystery Poem', 'Gloriana's Galaxy - The Mystery of Shakespeare', 'The Joy of Laughing, Hungry as a Hunter', Intellectual Pleasure', 'The Hero', 'Great Love; Son of Joy', 'Spiders', 'To A Wren', 'From Generation to Generation', 'Doubting Thomas', 'In Every Room', 'The Welcome', 'By Candlelight', 'O Ancient Curse of Poets', 'New York in the first Snowfall - The Polar Star', '19, Union Square West, the smell of New York' for Tennessee Williams, for Roger Straus', 'Eighth Avenue. New York City', New York' (?), untitled poem about New York, 'Letter to Mr. Nash (Bournemouth printer)', 'New York in Spring Transition', untitled poem about New York (2 May), 'Essay on Writing', 'An Essay on Pornography', Essay on 'English History' and 'The Seven Bishops', 'What is Law, & what is the administration of it' - an essay, 'A Perfect Rose' - a short story, Anna de Noailles, notes on Willa Cather, and 'Miscellany'.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous writings: diaries, journals, and notes on poems

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: 'Venetian Boatman's Song', 'Raiders over the Danube' - a short story, 'Frontier Town' - a short story, 'Decoration' - a short story, 'Mr. Tully's Revenge' - a short story, 'There is my delight' and 'Silence', 'Hot September Day', 'Brown Thistles', 'The Beauty of Silence', 'Early Spring', 'The Sea and Solitude', 'On the Lover', 'Fujiama', 'Storm in an old Garden', 'On the dotted line', 'A Portrait in Cameo - A Crown of Words - for Edinburgh', 'The Consolation', 'Espana', 'Night Convoy on the Uplands', 'Sacquara' - a dull silver poem, 'Renferries Hall', 'The Clock in the Arcade' - a story, an untitled story, 'The World Wakes Early', 'Two Poems for Christmas', and various other miscellaneous works.

did.unittitle: Poetry dedicated to: Walter Rushmore, and others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains poetry dedicated to: Bruce Chatwin (writer, 1940-1988), Tim Batsford, Marie Belloc Lowndes (novelist, 1868-1947), Stephen Vincent Benét (writer, 1898-1943), Sir John Betjeman (poet, 1906-1984), Dr. Brian Batten (Stephen Tennant's doctor), Fred Burdett, Joan Collins (actress, 1933- ), Peter Croft, Emily Dickinson (poet, 1830-1886), E.M. Foster (writer, 1879-1970), Simon Fleet (neighbor, 1913-1966), Robert Frost (poet, 1874-1963), Pauline Graham, Chester Kallman (poet and lover of W.H. Auden, 1921-1975), Sidney Keyes, Philip Larkin (poet, 1922-1985), Edna St. Vincent Millay (writer, 1892-1950), Peter Owen (publisher), John Pitt-Rivers (neighbor), Ruth Pitter (poet, 1897-1992), Walter Rushmore, and Derek Salbeg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains: poems referring to Dylan Thomas (poet, 1914-1953), Sir William Walton (composer, 1902-1983), Laurence Whistler (glass engraver, 1912-2000) and his wife Therea Furse, L.W. [Lawrence Whistler?], Mary Wilson (poet, wife of Harold Wilson, British Prime Minister), Wilkie (?), and Elinor Wylie (poet, 1885-1928). Also includes various posthumous dedications, to John Keats, Virigina Woolf, Rupert Brooke, T.S. Eliot, and Cavafy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains dedications to: Jonathan Cape, Leslie Hotson, Laurie [Lawrence Whistler?], Ivry (Lady) Freyberg, Arvid de Bodisco (Estonian writer), Franze Lehar, Sir Arthur Bryant (historian, 1899-1985), Garcia Lorca, Martin Hynes, Deborah Taylour, Ina Claire (actress, 1892-1985), P.N. Furbank (biographer of Forster), Gervaise Jackson-Stops (architectural historian), Editor of A.A. Chronicle, Elizabeth and Susan Belloc Lowndes, Wilfred Owen (poet), T. Parkinson, Sir Robert Helpmann (dancer, 1909-1986), Diana Menuhin (ballerina, as Diana Gould, wife of Yehudi Menuhin), Bernice Slote (Willa Cather scholor), Rosemary and Joan Oliver (neighbors, nieces of Edith Olivier), Barbara Hutton (heiress, 1913-1979), Anne Marie Gilbert, and various unknown dedications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ruth Mayhew (d. 1939) was the wife of Sir Henry Head (1861-1940), a neurologist and old friend of Siegfried Sassoon's, whom he met through Dr. Rivers. These letters contain references to Sassoon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edith Lewis (1883-1972) was the friend and companion of Willa Cather. After Cather's death in 1947, Edith Lewis' friendship with Stephen Tennant grew. Edith Lewis and Stephen Tennant shared travels together throughout Europe and the Pacific.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly alphabetical correspondence to and from Stephen Tennant, with poems dedicated by Stephen Tennant to various individuals.
